title: November 4
description:
Rome, the Eternal City. It's a fascinating place but rough with kids. Since Milo has a hard time grasping 30 days from now, 3000 years of history is a bit much.

We found ways to make it work. Dean and Lucie loved it, Felix was quite captivated by lots of it, and Milo was bribed with a never-ending succession of gelatos and the very occasional stop at an internet cafe to play some Club Penguin.

children.title: Colosseum
children.description: First stop on any boy's tour of Rome:  the Colosseum.

children.title: Colosseum 2
children.description:
We were impressed by the system of ramps and elevators that brought beasts up through the floor to battle the gladiators.

The elevators were shielded by baffles so that the gladiators didn't know where the animals had come up. The nosebleed seats could see the animals over the baffles, and their knowing laughter rang down upon the fighter, who was frantically turning to keep from being attacked from behind.

Good clean fun for the whole family!

children.title: Colosseum 3
children.description: Hot sunny Rome is known as a hard place for a tourist to find a drink of water.  We had no problem.

children.title: Pantheon
children.description: It was difficult to shelter from the rain; even the Pantheon was sopping wet inside.

children.title: Pantheon 2
children.description:
See? Someone left a big ol' hole in the middle of the Pantheon to create a huge wet mess on the slick marble floors.

The Pantheon used to be one-stop-shopping to worship all the Roman gods (there were more than 30,000 of them!). It survived destruction in the medieval period because it was re-consecrated as a Catholic church.

As it was consecrated by Pope Boniface IV, a demon flew out of the ground and escaped by butting its horns against the ceiling to create the hole. Or so they say.

children.title: Halloween
children.description:
October 31. Halloween. What's a pagan family to do when stranded 6000 miles from the most important ritual of the year?

Why, buy some candy and improvise in the hotel room!

In what has been universally acknowledged as the lamest Halloween ever, Felix dressed up as Percy Jackson (note the pen, which turns into a celestial bronze sword). Milo was a Puffle from Club Penguin (he wore his Puffle cap).

Dean stuffed himself in the armoire, answering the kids' knocks on the door. Lucie set up a candy station on the bed.

children.title: Halloween 2
children.description: To bulk out the number of "houses" the kids visited, we enlisted every toy and cup in the room to hand out candy.

children.title: Halloween 3
children.description:
With Halloween, the journey is as important as the destination.

However, it must be said that when the destination is a hoard of candy, the lameness of the journey CAN and mostly DID get overlooked.

children.title: Grim Reaper
children.description:
But wait, Halloween isn't over yet! In our attempts to make culture exciting for 6 year olds, we keep ending up at creep-o-rama places like this. It's a chapel/crypt for Capucin monks beneath the church of Santa Maria della Concezione. Quite near the Hard Rock Cafe.

It's decked out in the bones of 4000 previous monk residents of the church. Why? Real estate! The floors are earth from the Holy Land. Capucin monks were buried in it, but when it filled up, long-dead bodies were disinterred to make room for new occupants. Four thousand skeletons dating between 1528 and 1870 were used to decorate the chapel.

Our favorite is the Grim Reaper in this photo: the blade of his scythe is a column of tail bones, and he's holding a bone scale to weigh the souls of the dead.

The whole joint serves to remind people of their mortality, as stated by an inscription near the mummified remains of one monk:

“Quello che voi siete noi eravamo, Quello che noi siamo voi sarete.” - What you are now we were, What we are you will be.

children.title: Trevi Fountain
children.description:
Rome can be described as a series of walks punctuated by fountains.

This is the Trevi fountain, one of the most famous. We'd pass by in the morning, fresh and ready for the first activity of the day, and then drag ourselves past it again in the evening, cranky and wanting some play time at the hotel.

children.title: Fountain of the Four Rivers
children.description:
Two exhausted boys at Piazza Navona's Fountain of the Four Rivers.

Not even the world-famous gelato at the nearby Tre Scalini cafe could pick up these tired puppies.

children.title: St. Peter's Basilica
children.description:
St. Peter's Basilica, the greatest of all churches in Christendom. Also, a useful landmark for navigating the city.

Our humble thanks to God for providing such a dramatic cloudscape.

children.title: Baby Moses
children.description:
What trip to Rome would be complete without seeing baby Moses about to be placed into the Nile?

Felix and Milo both spent the first 3 months of their lives in a wicker basket called a Moses basket just like this one. See Milo in his Moses basket and see Felix in his.

children.title: Hippocampi
children.description:
Milo's interested in exercising to get big muscles, but only has the patience to do it for 15 seconds. Here, Dean holds him to 10 reps.

We like this fountain — the Fontana dei Cavalli Marini — because it has hippocampi (mythological sea horses). They feature prominently in Percy Jackson and the Olympians, a series that Dean's been reading at night to all of us.

We picked up Percy Jackson when we stopped Harry Potter after the 4th book. Harry Potter book five would have been too boring for Milo with all of the focus on teenage angst.

children.title: Bikes
children.description: Rental bikes in Villa Borghese, the Central Park of Rome.

children.title: Villa Borghese Sunset
children.description:
To us, Villa Borghese at sunset felt like Africa: the dramatic sky, the massive flocks of birds, the umbrella pines that resemble the Serengeti's acacia trees.

The only difference, really, is all the 500 year old villas sprinkling the park.

children.title: Hard Rock Cafe
children.description:
After more than a week of ravioli, lasagna and spaghetti with mussels, the boys begged for a taste of the old homeland.

We took them to the Hard Rock Cafe where they scarfed down hot dogs and the latest music videos.

We're really impressed they pulled Michelangelo out of retirement to paint that ceiling!

children.title: Forum Rubble
children.description:
The center of ancient Rome was the Forum, seat of government and commerce for a thousand years.

Now it's big chunks of rubble for small children to climb on.

children.title: Timeout in the Forum
children.description:
Truly, it's exhausting to mentally reconstruct greatness out of mounds of rubble.

Sometimes everybody just needs a time out.

children.title: Gallery of Maps
children.description:
We nearly didn't go to the Vatican. The kids were burnt out on monuments and museums and we couldn't pique their interest with talk of the Pope or the Renaissance or one of the holiest places in all of Christendom.

Finally, we took them on our last morning in Italy, when they were fresh and knew that the reward for toughing this one out was a plane flight back to their toys, rooms and bathtub in Paris.

We were so glad we made it! An incredible place.

This is the Gallery of Maps. Yes, the ceiling IS that brilliantly golden.

children.title: Gallery of Maps
children.description:
The Gallery of Maps show all the Italian regions and the papal properties of the 1580's.

Lucie's favorite: this one of Liguria (north-west Italy). We're thinking of painting a copy on a wall in the house in Paris, as a present for our host family when they return from Berkeley.

children.title: Sistine Chapel
children.description: Finally, art even Milo recognized:  God and Man touching fingers in the Sistine Chapel.
